content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A certain variety of rosebush is known to produce a large number of rose blooms during the blooming period. Heather, a botanist (plant expert), plans to investigate the number of rose blooms on the rosebush during the blooming period.

Suppose the probability is <math alttext="0.63" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.63</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that a rosebush from a certain nursery with a large number of rosebushes of this variety has at least <math alttext="75" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> rose blooms during the blooming period. Heather selected a random sample of <math alttext="32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> rosebushes from the large population of rosebushes of this variety at the nursery and recorded the number of rose blooms observed during the blooming period for each rosebush in the sample.
(a) In the context of Heather’s sample, interpret the meaning of the value computed by <math alttext="open parenthesis, 1 minus 0.63, close parenthesis, to the 32 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.63</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A certain variety of rosebush is known to produce a large number of rose blooms during the blooming period. Heather, a botanist (plant expert), plans to investigate the number of rose blooms on the rosebush during the blooming period.

Suppose the probability is <math alttext="0.63" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.63</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that a rosebush from a certain nursery with a large number of rosebushes of this variety has at least <math alttext="75" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> rose blooms during the blooming period. Heather selected a random sample of <math alttext="32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> rosebushes from the large population of rosebushes of this variety at the nursery and recorded the number of rose blooms observed during the blooming period for each rosebush in the sample.
(a) In the context of Heather’s sample, interpret the meaning of the value computed by <math alttext="open parenthesis, 1 minus 0.63, close parenthesis, to the 32 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.63</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The computer output below provides the summary statistics of the number of rose blooms during the blooming period for each of the <math alttext="32" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> rosebushes in Heather’s sample.

Mean
 Standard Deviation
 Median
 Min
 Max
 <math alttext="Q 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="q 3" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle mathvariant="normal"> <mrow> <mi>Q</mi> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>

<math alttext="78" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="79" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>79</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="49" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>49</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="97" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>97</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="65" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>65</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="83" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>83</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) Would it be unusual for a rosebush from Heather’s sample to have <math alttext="96" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>96</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> rose blooms during the blooming period? Justify your answer.

(c) Consider the situation where the number of rose blooms for one rosebush was incorrectly recorded as <math alttext="52" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>52</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is actually <math alttext="57" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>57</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Describe the effect that an increase in the number of rose blooms from <math alttext="52" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>52</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="57" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>57</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for this rosebush would have on the mean and median of Heather’s sample. Explain your reasoning.

Heather plans to use the sample data to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence that all rosebushes of this variety at the nursery have a mean number of rose blooms during the blooming period greater than <math alttext="75" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(d) State, in words, the hypotheses for the appropriate test.

Assume all conditions for inference are met. The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of Heather’s test was approximately <math alttext="0.084" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.084</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(e) Interpret what the value <math alttext="0.084" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.084</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> measures in the context of the study.

Charlie, another botanist, selected a new random sample from the population of all rosebushes of this variety at the nursery and also obtained a sample mean of <math alttext="78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. He then conducted the same inference procedure as Heather had in order to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence that all rosebushes of this variety at the nursery have a mean number of rose blooms during the blooming period greater than <math alttext="75" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of Charlie’s test was approximately <math alttext="0.03" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.03</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(f) Identify one possible difference between Heather’s and Charlie’s samples that resulted in Charlie’s test having a smaller <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value. Explain how this difference results in a smaller <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value for Charlie’s test.

topic.text: 1.7: Summary Statistics for a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Identify null and alternative hypotheses.
